quickScenarioChallenge.challengeSubtitle: Don't worry if you get it wrong‚Äîthat's how you learn!
quickScenarioChallenge.scenarioStory: Your Scrum team is in the middle of a Sprint. The Product Owner keeps interrupting developers with new requests. The Scrum Master is acting like a project manager, assigning tasks and tracking hours. Sprint Reviews are skipped because 'everyone is too busy.' The team hasn't held a Retrospective in three Sprints.
quickScenarioChallenge.question: What are the PRIMARY problems here?

options.A: The team needs to work harder to accommodate the Product Owner's requests
options.B: Scrum roles, events, and artifacts are being violated‚ÄîSprint integrity, SM role, and inspect-adapt cycle
options.C: The Scrum Master should assign tasks more efficiently
options.D: Skip Sprint Planning to save time for actual work

ahaDebrief.correctAnswer: B - Scrum roles, events, and artifacts are being violated‚ÄîSprint integrity, SM role, and inspect-adapt cycle

insights.explanation: Once a Sprint starts, no changes should threaten the Sprint Goal. The PO is violating this.
insights.pmbokSupport: Scrum Guide: During the Sprint, no changes are made that would endanger the Sprint Goal

insights.explanation: The SM should facilitate and remove impediments, not command-and-control
insights.pmbokSupport: Scrum Guide: The Scrum Master serves the team by facilitating, coaching, and removing impediments

insights.explanation: Sprint Review and Retrospective are essential for inspection and adaptation
insights.pmbokSupport: Scrum Guide: Sprint Review inspects the product; Retrospective inspects the process

insights.explanation: Developers should choose how to do their work, not be assigned tasks
insights.pmbokSupport: Scrum Guide: Developers self-organize to accomplish the Sprint Goal

trapSection.explanation: Options A, C, and D miss the core Scrum violations and suggest anti-patterns.

trapTable.violation: Accepting mid-Sprint changes threatens Sprint Goal and team focus
Scrum Master as task-master contradicts servant leadership
trapTable.pmiValueBroken: Violates Scrum Master role and team self-organization

patternRecognition.patternRule: Scrum's 3-5-3 structure (3 roles, 5 events, 3 artifacts) creates discipline. Skipping elements breaks the framework and eliminates transparency, inspection, and adaptation.

coreFramework.frameworkIntro: Scrum is the most popular Agile framework. Master the 3 roles, 5 events, and 3 artifacts:

rows.action: Maximizes product value; owns and orders Product Backlog
rows.examKeywords: value, priority, backlog owner, stakeholder voice

rows.action: Servant leader; facilitates, coaches, removes impediments
Self-organizing team that creates the increment
1-4 week timebox; fixed length; contains all other events
rows.examKeywords: timebox, iteration, Sprint Goal, fixed duration

rows.action: Plan the Sprint: What & How? Creates Sprint Backlog
rows.examKeywords: Sprint Goal, Sprint Backlog, commitment, capacity

rows.action: 15-min daily sync; inspect progress toward Goal; adapt plan
Inspect the Increment with stakeholders; adapt Product Backlog
rows.examKeywords: demo, stakeholder feedback, inspect product, adapt backlog

rows.action: Inspect the process; identify improvements for next Sprint
Ordered list of everything needed; owned by PO; emergent
Selected Product Backlog Items + plan; owned by Developers
rows.examKeywords: Sprint Goal, commitment, Dev team owns, plan

rows.action: Usable, 'Done' product at end of Sprint; meets DoD
rows.examKeywords: Done, usable, potentially releasable, Definition of Done

3 ROLES: Product Owner, Scrum Master, Developers

5 EVENTS: Sprint (Planning, Daily, Review, Retro)

3 ARTIFACTS: Product Backlog, Sprint Backlog, Increment

Each has a COMMITMENT: Product Goal, Sprint Goal, Definition of Done

pmbokConnection.quote: Scrum is founded on empiricism and lean thinking. Empiricism asserts that knowledge comes from experience and making decisions based on what is observed.

steps: 5 EVENTS: Sprint > Planning > Daily > Review > Retro
3 ARTIFACTS: Product Backlog, Sprint Backlog, Increment
Each artifact has a COMMITMENT: Product Goal, Sprint Goal, DoD

visualReferenceCard.quickReference: Scrum creates transparency through artifacts, inspection through events, and adaptation through empiricism.
visualReferenceCard.goldenRule: Don't skip Scrum events‚Äîeach serves a specific inspect-adapt purpose. Don't violate Sprint integrity by accepting mid-Sprint changes.
visualReferenceCard.examTip: Exam loves to test: Who owns what? (PO owns Product Backlog, Devs own Sprint Backlog). What happens in each event? Can you skip events? (No!)
visualReferenceCard.pmbokPrinciple: Scrum is built on empiricism: transparency, inspection, adaptation

secondScenario.title: Apply the Scrum Framework
secondScenario.intro: Now that you know the framework, let's apply it to a new situation.
secondScenario.scenarioStory: Your Sprint Review revealed that the team completed all planned work, but stakeholders are unhappy because the features don't address their current needs. The Product Owner admits they haven't updated the Product Backlog in weeks and haven't talked to stakeholders. What should happen?
secondScenario.question: What's the PRIMARY issue and solution?

options.A: The Developers should have talked to stakeholders directly during the Sprint
options.B: The Product Owner failed to engage stakeholders and maintain the Product Backlog; they need to adapt
options.C: The Scrum Master should take over Product Backlog management
options.D: Cancel the next Sprint to rebuild the Product Backlog

quotes.text: Scrum is founded on empiricism and lean thinking. Empiricism asserts that knowledge comes from experience and making decisions based on what is observed. Lean thinking reduces waste and focuses on the essentials.
quotes.author: Ken Schwaber & Jeff Sutherland

quotes.text: The exam will test if you know WHO owns WHAT. PO owns Product Backlog (the 'what'). Developers own Sprint Backlog (the 'how'). SM owns nothing‚Äîthey serve. Get these ownership boundaries clear!
quotes.author: PMP Instructor Insight

fieldInsights.title: Real-World Application
fieldInsights.insight: Many teams claim to do Scrum but skip Retrospectives or let the PO interrupt Sprints. This is 'Scrum-but' or 'Zombie Scrum.' Real Scrum requires ALL roles, ALL events, ALL artifacts. The discipline creates the results.

fieldInsights.title: Exam Strategy
fieldInsights.insight: When you see a Scrum question, identify: Which role? Which event? Which artifact? Then apply the rules: PO maximizes value, SM facilitates, Devs self-organize, events enable inspect-adapt, artifacts create transparency.

memoryPalace.title: üèîÔ∏è Memory Palace: The Scrum Mountain Expedition
memoryPalace.intro: Anchor the Scrum framework with this vivid mountain climbing story. As you read, visualize each scene:

story.title: The 3-5-3 Climb
story.narrative: You're climbing Scrum Mountain with a specific expedition structure: 3 key people, 5 checkpoints, and 3 essential supplies.

scenes.description: Three distinct climbers: The PRODUCT OWNER (wearing a golden 'Value' badge) scouts ahead to find the most valuable route. The SCRUM MASTER (carrying tools) removes obstacles and facilitates the journey. The DEVELOPERS (a self-organizing team of 5-9 climbers) actually climb the mountain together.
You enter a large transparent container labeled '1-4 weeks.' Everything happens inside this container. You can see through it, but nothing from outside can break in (protecting the Sprint Goal).
Inside the container, you start at Planning Base Camp. The team gathers around a map: WHAT can we climb in this Sprint? HOW will we do it? They create the Sprint Backlog and commit to a Sprint Goal.
Every morning at the same time, the team meets at a checkpoint for exactly 15 minutes. They sync: Are we on track? What's blocking us? How do we adapt our plan?

At the end of the Sprint, everyone gathers at a scenic viewpoint. The team shows what they climbed (the Increment). Stakeholders provide feedback. The PO adapts the Product Backlog based on what they learned.
The team stands by Mirror Lake and reflects on HOW they worked together. What went well? What can we improve? They commit to one improvement for the next Sprint.

Three transparent backpacks: 1) PRODUCT BACKLOG (all future climbs, owned by PO, with Product Goal flag) 2) SPRINT BACKLOG (this Sprint's plan, owned by Developers, with Sprint Goal flag) 3) INCREMENT (the actual progress made, marked 'Done' with Definition of Done stamp).

story.moral: The 3-5-3 structure creates discipline and transparency. Skipping roles, events, or artifacts breaks the framework and eliminates the empirical process.

memoryPalace.selfTest: Close your eyes and walk through the Scrum Mountain climb. Can you recall the 3 roles, 5 events (in order), and 3 artifacts?
